bibl.title: Excerpt of letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, July 28, 1921

div1.p: Hanson reports on mosquito work in Peru, where he thinks they have been successful.

div1.head: Excerpt of letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, July 28, 1921
div1.p:
Excerpt of letter to Mr. Wickliffe Rose from Henry Hanson, Chiclayo, July
28, 1921.

At present Dr. Enrique Caballero, Mr. John P. Corrigan, and
Inspector Arturo Sainz are working in the northern section of the Department
of Ancash, with instructions to work everything of importance from the north
towards the south. The object of this is to avoid the possibility of any
repetition of what has occured this year. It may not be absolutely necessary,
but it is very much safer to do it, and I think Dr. White agrees that it is worth
doing. The breeding in this section was reported to be extremely high. The
plan there is to limit the work entirely to the use of fish in so far as
possible, which will result more economically both in time and money.

For the future we can concentrate more on the larger places, and
discontinue what we have been doing in the smaller places up to the time we
were certain of the extent of the propagation.

In about another month I think we shall know with reasonable certainty
what the final outcome is to be. It is about a month since we have had any re-
ported cases from any place in this Department, and the mosquito index is low
and decreasing. The entire province of Pacasmayo is completely safe, with an
average stegomya index which does not reach one percent. All the balance of the
Department of Libertad with the exception of Casa Grande is in satisfactory
condition, and the whole thing has brought about somewhat of a relaxation of the
intense anxiety under which we were working for four months and a half.

At present all our work is paralyzed for about a week on account of the
Centenniel Celebration, and it is useless to try to work under such conditions.
Fortunately we have practically everything in such shape that it will not do
us much harm.
